text: hi everybody I'm Brandon and this is
Randall and today we're gonna talk to
you a little bit about how to use the
AWS CLI which is the command line
interface for AWS so what exactly is a
command line interface yeah so a command
line interface allows you to interact
with a system from a terminal or a shell
instead of using a visual interface like
you would accessing AWS console with
your web browser so that gives you some
advantages right yeah one of my favorite
things about the AWS CLI is that it's
actually programmatically created and
determined
so whenever the AWS API is update the
CLI is already available and updated for
you so what happens is the AWS CLI is an
interface on top of Python framework
called boto
that goes out and pulls in all of these
JSON files that define how the API is
above it for eight of us work and this
allows you to create really really
powerful programmatic constructs when
you're interacting with AWS so when it
comes to installing the the AWS CLI you
have a couple of dependencies and one of
those is Python one of the things that I
do and OSX or Mac is I just do brew
install AWS CLI and that normally pulls
in everything for me and gets it working
and that uses a package manager called
homebrew one of the other ways of
installing it would just be to say pip
install AWS CLI and that should just get
everything running and if you run into
any issues don't worry we have a helpful
little web page that'll tell you all the
different kind of troubleshooting tips
if you have any dependency issues yeah
you can get started with the CLI learn
how to install it how to get it
configured and how they start using it
AWS amazon.com slash CLI and yet one of
the one of the things that I think is
really a big advantage of using the CLI
is that you get repeatability right
instead of having to know a certain
sequence of clicks and where to find
things in the web interface to spin up a
new server you can script it out and use
the CLI to do that right so one of the
really cool features is actually the
ability to go in and write queries after
you've you know done all your filtering
on the server side to even further
filter down your results so I have one
of my favorite services is AWS poly and
so you can say something like AWS poly
describe voices and that'll give you all
the different voices that are available
and then you can say you know output
text and that will give you all the
different texts
all the different voices that are
available in the languages and stuff
like that but what's really cool is you
can write a little james path query to
go and give you just the names of those
voices so that's all those names of
those voices and json so all in all I
think the tool is pretty full-featured
and it lets you build out whatever kind
of programmatic constructs you want on
top of regular batch scripts cool that's
definitely very powerful and one way you
might want to consider using this is if
you're manually spending off ec2
instances you can put some of these
commands into your user data script so
that they run automatically when those
instances come up which is useful for
syncing files between servers using s3
and things like that so again thank you
for joining us to learn how to get
started with AWS CLI go to
aws.amazon.com slash CLI to learn more
